newsitem.title: CHINA: China nuclear power output up 12 pct in 1996.
newsitem.headline: China nuclear power output up 12 pct in 1996.

text.p: China's nuclear power output reached 14.3 billion kilowatt hours in 1996, climbing by 12 percent compared with the previous year, the Xinhua news agency said in an overnight report.

The Qinshan nuclear power plant in eastern Zhejiang province generated 2.23 billion kilowatt hours, while the Daya Bay plant in southern Guangdong Province produced 12.11 billion kilowatt hours, it said.

Last year, the utilisation rate of generating units at Qinshan reached 84.6 percent while the rate at Daya Bay, which lies near Hong Kong, was 72.6 percent, it quoted officials at a conference of China National Nuclear Corporation as saying.
That compared with an average in 1995 of 81.3 percent.
In 1996, output of nuclear power accounted for just one percent of China's total power output, it said.
China's nuclear power sector should increase its proportion of the country's power structure, in which thermal power accounts for 75 percent and hydropower for 24 percent.
"China must boost nuclear power for its economic construction," Xinhua quoted a corporation official as saying.
China plans to build four new nuclear power plants with a total generating capacity of 6,900 megawatts in the next few years.
China's nuclear industry would not take off until the next century, when nuclear generating capacity is forecast to increase to 20,000 megawatts from the current 2,100 megawatts, the official said.
